title: Marianne Faithfull webchat â as it happened | Culture | The Guardian
summary: `` my favourite writer is shakespeare - hamlet is my favourite . ''
`` i am just coming to terms with being disabled , and i 'm not in the mood for writing songs at the moment . ''
`` being taken seriously was absolutely impossible : i was a 'chick ' . ''
`` how has the internet changed things ? artists are n't really getting paid any more . ''
`` terry wogan was always incredibly kind and good to me . ''
`` what i like about making records and performing is that it 's under my control . ''

documents.title: that 's everything from marianne .
text: guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:23pm goodbye everyone - thank you for all your lovely questions .
i enjoyed talking to you very much .
daniel theodore tobilius watkins says : my question is , will you ever perform an evening in the weimar republic type of show/ the songs of 20th century blues or similar again ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:22pm no - that ship has sailed .
tomorrow i will be doing a broad mixture of different songs from all different periods of my life .
and maybe , but only maybe , warren ellis is coming- but that 's not for sure .

documents.title: `` my favourite writer is shakespeare - hamlet is my favourite . ''
text: lilz zocca asks : my question to you is , which books do you consider your absolute favorites , classic literature or not ?
if you do n't mind , may i also ask about your likes in the last couple of decades ' music and movies ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:20pm i read at least three books at a time , i love the classics of course - happy birthday anton chekhov .
my favourite writer is shakespeare - hamlet is my favourite .
i have my own little hamlet , my son .
not so much now , he 's grown up , but when he was younger he was very like hamlet .
but i love nick tosches , i love william burroughs , gregory corsair , keats , shelley , byron .
i 'm reading a great book about mitterand , which is very interesting .
and penny arcade 's book , longing lasts longer , which is very good .
great title , by the way .
id707714 asks : what is your relationship to dance given that , your mother was a dancer , and that you have recently worked with the prima ballerina , marie-agnã¨s gillot ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:18pm the etoile of paris .
marie-agnes is one of my dearest friends , i love doing projects with her , but i most love going to the opera to watch her dance .
i think of it as a good evening out .
i only saw my mother dance when she was with my father - she was very traumatised , after the war .
she did a dance in the drawing room to beethoven 's fifth - i must have been five .
and she danced the story of persephone , when i was about five or six .
my mouth just fell open .
it 's the first time i realised my mother was acting a tragedy .

documents.title: `` i am just coming to terms with being disabled , and i 'm not in the mood for writing songs at the moment . ''
text: id8897733 asks : what is your ty day when you are at home ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:16pm well , i wake up very early .
i play with the computer for a bit , i squeeze two clementines and have a natural yoghurt , and one or two cups of lapsang souchong .
then i do my inhalations for my emphysema , and then i go back to bed until 8.30 .
and then rochelle comes and makes my vegetable juice - beetroot , ginger , two green apples , and carrot , plus two pieces of brown toast with marmalade , and coffee .
and then , if i can stand it , i go for a little walk down the boulevard .
and then i have my lunch , which is very healthy , salad or spinach with poached eggs .
then a little nap , then i get up , and i might go for another little walk .
i 've just been through three years when i 've had the most terrible accidents , including a bone infection .
i am just coming to terms with being disabled , and i 'm not in the mood for writing songs at the moment .
it will happen .
it 's good for me to come to london and play the roundhouse this week - i 'm happiest when i 'm performing .
i put so much into give my love to london , and i like it better than broken english , the famous comeback album - give me love to london is much more brilliant .
i do n't see a new record coming out for the next year and a half , but i have the live record coming out .
it 's soon .
coedy marwood has four questions , including : 3 .
is there anyone who you have n't collaborated with whom you would like to collaborate in the future ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:12pm 3 .
no .
why should i !
i 've collaborated with everyone i 've wanted to ; i know how lucky i am , the people i work with now are the best .
one of the things i learned in the theatre is repertory , doing things with the same people again and again , and that way you refine it .
glennbrox wants to know : after 50 years in music , what keeps you inspired ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:11pm the music .
my music .
my band , the people i work with .
music is my life .
i draw inspiration for songs from absolutely anywhere - not just myself .
i 've got ideas at the moment , but they 're cooking , and i have n't got to the writing bit yet .
they cook in my head .
id8897733 asks : you said in an interview that you are likely to record eps rather than full albums in the future .
is that still the case ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:10pm well , no , i never meant only eps , it was something that i would like to do - and then go back to albums .
it 's not written in stone , it was just a thought .
maybe because i 'm lazy and it 's less songs to write !
and also because i do remember when i was a teenager , i really did enjoy eps myself .

documents.title: `` being taken seriously was absolutely impossible : i was a 'chick ' . ''
text: ohohcheri says : first of all i just want to say that you 're such a badass woman and truly someone that inspires me as a teenage girl !
if you do n't mind , i have two questions ; was/is it hard being a woman in this industry and being taken seriously as an artist ?

and i hope this is n't inappropriate or offensive but i wonder if you have any nice memories or kind words of brian jones , i feel like some people tend to paint him as a mean , sad and almost pitiful person , and so i just wondered if that was always the case or if it 's a one-sided portrayal of him ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:08pm being taken seriously was absolutely impossible .
i was n't even a woman in those days , i was a `` chick '' .
it 's taken a very long time to be taken seriously .

i do n't people to take me deadly seriously , that 's the wrong impression , i 'm not that serious myself- but i am a musician , a writer , and i do make records and performances , and they 're good , and i know that .
you have to have compassion for brian .
in the beginning he was brilliant , and it was his idea , the rolling stones - his problem was he could n't write songs , and mick and keith could , but he sure could play .
and of course , he was very beautiful .
i ca n't say i liked him , but i have nothing against him .
he did n't deserve to be murdered .

documents.title: `` how has the internet changed things ? artists are n't really getting paid any more . ''
text: magdalena bee says : i love the phrase candyfloss techno hell ' from sparrows will sing .
it seems to be alluding to the fact that modern technology is changing humans for the worse .
how do you feel about modern technology like the internet and smartphones ?
and how has the internet changed the music industry or the workflow of working artists like yourself ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:06pm that was written by roger waters .
i would n't have an iphone if they gold-plated it - i hate that kind of thing .
i have to have a laptop i know i could n't work an iphone .
and how do i know how the internet has changed things ? ?
artists are n't really getting paid any more - that 's how it 's changed .
derekdasilva says : you and barry reynolds wrote a song that i think is one of grace jones best performances .
i 'm wondering how it came to be .
was it a cast off from one of your records that then barry later brought in when working with grace ?
or was it written just for her ?
and without ruining the world weary enigma of the song , is there anything you might say about it ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:04pm barry wrote most of it , he wrote the book actually - and i wrote some of the verses .
i remember particularly the one about jenny lin - i was there when jenny lind first sang i ca n't remember what it meant but i wrote it !
reve88 asks : what was it like to work with derek jarman ?
( loved that short film for broken english ) .
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:03pm derek jarman , it was very interesting , and fast , which i liked very much .
he was wonderful .
at the time , nobody understood it , island records did n't get it ; it was n't the sort of film they put on mtv .

documents.title: `` terry wogan was always incredibly kind and good to me . ''
text: jessbrown1984 says : i was very sad to hear of the passing of terry wogan .
i heard your interview with him a couple of years ago , what are your fondest memories of him ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:02pm he was always incredibly kind and good to me .
the most wonderful moment in my friendship with terry was when he was doing his television chat show , and i had just got clean and sober .
my father was still alive , and he was so proud - my poor father had watched people put me down for years , and of course he knew me , and knew i was nothing like how the press made me out .
and it hurt him .
and terry wogan made him proud , and i thought that was wonderful .
it was n't just being on the show , it was how terry wogan was with me , his questions .
he stood for something - if i really had been what i was represented as , they would n't have wanted me .
we had a wonderful time in that last interview , and i told him that story - he was very pleased .

documents.title: `` what i like about making records and performing is that it 's under my control . ''
text: snazpizaz asks : do you ever act movie these days ?
do any offers come your way ?
is there a role or director you would like to work with ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 2:59pm offers come my way all the time , and i turn them down .
i 'm not doing absolutely fabulous for example - though they did n't ask me .
i loved working with jennifer , but that ship has sailed .
it 's like the paintings , but much worse - you have no control .
and what i like about making records and performing is that it 's under my control .
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 3:00pm i have not done everything i wanted - but i did get off alcohol and drugs , and that 's why i 'm still alive .
and at the time , i did not want to - but now i 'm very glad i did .
i now see there was a lot more to it than getting off alcohol and drugs .

documents.title: `` billie holiday and ella fitzgerald are the greatest . ''
text: jordan peers has another question : your various covers of bob dylan and leonard cohen songs are among some of my favourite in your whole repertoire and they are both clearly quite influential to you .
what female artists of past or present would you hold in similarly high regard ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 2:57pm billie holiday .
i think she 's the greatest , and then ella fitzgerald .
how do i know why they 're great !
they were born that way .

one of the things i love about holiday - apart from her voice , her songs and her band - was the way she lived her life : she always did what she wanted , in the way she wanted ; no-one could tell her what to do .
which is probably why she had such a difficult time in the music business .
there 's also memphis minnie , and aretha franklin - who i call the voice of god .
jordan peers says : as a portrait painter there would be few people more interesting , iconic or inspiring to paint than you , yet there seem to be no painted portraits of you .
have you been approached by any artists wishing to paint you and would you have any desire to sit for one if they did ?

( i used your song mother wolf as a title for a painting of my mother last year ) guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 2:55pm i was just painted by anthony palliser , who is an artist living in paris and a friend of mine - he did a lovely portrait of me , and apparently people like it very much .
we 're hoping the national portrait gallery will want it .
i 've also been painted by felix topolsky , and nigel weymouth .
it 's a bit of shock seeing it afterwards !
but i was always pleased .
they were n't what i expected - they never are .
you have no control .
princeblimey says : can you talk about your connection to grace jones , please ?
she published a wise and wonderfully written autobiography last fall .
it was the best autobiography of a female musical artist that i have read since faithfull ' .
have you read it ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 2:53pm not yet , but i 'm longing to .
i love grace .
there are two sides to grace , and i love both - maybe one more than the other .
the little jamaican girl which is what she really is , and then the creation , of grace jones with the funny hair and everything .
i also think she 's got a great voice .
rely asks : what are your memories - if any - of portraying irina in three sisters at the royal court in 1967 ?
what was it like working with glendale jackson and edward bond ?

guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 2:51pm well , of course in the three sisters there were two others and me , plus michael gambon and others , and william gaskell , who taught me - i was 19 and had never been on stage like that - and took the time to teach me to project to the back of the theatre .
he took extra time to teach me , i learned an awful lot from him and the other actors .
working with glenda , and avril , was wonderful .
jack shepherd was in it too - still brilliant .

documents.title: `` you ca n't work when you 're high . ''
text: ruraliconoclast says : we saw you in tom waits ' black rider in london about a decade ago .
loved the show and you too - was n't the lighting design/production just amazing !

just wondering , since tom has written or said that he was saved by his wife and co-writer from a spiral of alcohol abuse , and your own history is of recovering from drug abuse - is the creativity you enjoy now the sweeter for being clean ?
or is the creativity just what it is , but the better for being healthier ?

guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 2:50pm ah yes , black rider - the genius robert wilson , who is a director , costume designer , and gets these things going - he does a lot of this kind of stuff .
and it 's always very similar - i do n't always like it .
i went to a production in paris of madama butterfly , and i thought it was ghastly !
but for the black rider , for the devil , the white makeup worked fantastically .
he 's very very good , very stylised .
but of course , to play the devil was a wonderful part .
i really have no idea how i was cast .
you ca n't work when you 're high .
i 'm glad i did n't have to be saved by tom waits wife .
i got a lot of help , but not that kind !
squirrelhead wants to know : do you ever ride through paris in a sports car with the warm wind in your hair and if so , would you recommend it ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 2:46pm yes , i 'd recommend it , but i have n't done it yet .
but i 'd recommend it if you 're young and have long blond hair ; i ca n't drive .
i think it 's a little unrealistic .
we begin with id2993509 , who asks : what was the insiration behind your recent wonderful song going home ' ?
also , leonard ?
guardian contributor mariannefaithfull 01 february 2016 2:45pm well , i did n't write it myself - it was written by the great leonard cohen , and it 's on ordinary problems .
of course , i have n't asked leonard what it 's about , but i think it 's about leonard 's guardian angel talking to him .
a lovely song .
yeah , it 's a song about dying .
a beautiful song about dying .

documents.title: marianne is in the building to answer your questions
text: marianne faithfull in the guardian offices .
beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for marianne faithfull
text: few can say they 've lived like marianne faithfull .
she was famously a muse and lover to mick jagger , who co-wrote the rolling stones ' sister morphine with her .

but from the early 1960s , her own career as a singer has taken in guitar-pop , punk , jazz , irish folk and more , partnering with everyone from david bowie to angelo badalamenti and metallica along the way .
she has become a touchstone for each subsequent generation of songwriters pj harvey , jarvis cocker , billy corgan and damon albarn all number among her latter-day collaborators .
ahead of an intimate concert at london 's roundhouse , she is joining us to answer your questions about her career , in a live webchat from 2.40pm on monday 1 february .
post your questions in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .

bulletin.text: After a 50-year career in music, Marianne Faithfull came in to answer your questions, covering everything from her favourite authors, why she no longer collaborates, and her memories of Terry Wogan.
